intro: Brackenridgea zanguebarica, commonly known as the East African cycad, is a unique member of the Cycadaceae family. It is characterized by its stout, unbranched trunk and large, pinnately compound leaves that can reach several meters in length. The plant produces cones rather than flowers, with male and female cones typically appearing on separate plants. Native to eastern Africa, it thrives in tropical and subtropical climates with well-drained soils. Due to its slow growth and conservation status, it is often cultivated in botanical gardens and conservation programs.
